thread.title: No. 8 Alabama survives scare from Tennessee, 19-14
thread.title_full: No. 8 Alabama survives scare from Tennessee, 19-14

title: No. 8 Alabama survives scare from Tennessee, 19-14
text:
Tennessee drops another close game after losing late lead in 19-14 loss to No. 8 Alabama By JOHN ZENOR AP Sports Writer   9:17   9:17   
People: 
Tennessee (480) 

TUSCALOOSA, Alabama â€” The Tennessee Volunteers once again went toe to toe with a ranked team until the bitter end. 
The result, though, was another close loss, this time 19-14 to No. 8 Alabama on Saturday in a game where the Volunteers held the lead for a few late minutes. 
Derrick Henry scored on a 14-yard run with 2:24 left and the Volunteers (3-4, 1-3 Southeastern Conference) couldn't answer. 
"Every loss is painful because you invest so much in it and everyone talked about the culture," Tennessee coach Butch Jones said. "We believed that we were going to win the football game coming here and we came up short." 
Henry was barely touched on his second touchdown of the game, though the 2-point pass from Jake Coker failed. Then it was the defense's turn. 
Alabama (7-1, 4-1) had two straight sacks and Ryan Anderson knocked the ball loose from Joshua Dobbs to preserve the victory. 
"My heart was about to jump out of my chest when the offense was on that last drive, when they punched it in," Tide cornerback Cyrus Jones said. "Then we did our job to seal the win." 
The Tide got plenty of help, with Tennessee missing three long field goals. 
The Volunteers took the lead on Jalen Hurd's 12-yard scoring run with 5:49 left. Alabama overwhelmed the 15-point underdogs from there. 
Coker moved Alabama downfield thanks to athletic catches by ArDarius Stewart and Calvin Ridley. Ridley made a leaping grab for a 15-yarder on third and 6 from the Tennessee 40. 
Then Coker turned it over to Henry, who continued a hot streak with 28 carries for 143 yards. 
Dobbs and Tennessee managed a first down before the sacks. Anderson jarred the ball loose and A'Shawn Robinson recovered it one-handed on the second one and rambled a few yards toward the end zone before getting toppled while former Vols quarterback Peyton Manning watched stunned from the sideline. 
The Vols wound up with their fourth loss by a touchdown or less, three of them to a Top 25 team. 
"It doesn't feel good, but there are a lot of learning opportunities," Dobbs said. "We can't let this loss beat us twice. We have to be ready to go, because Kentucky doesn't really care about what happened this weekend." 
Dobbs was 13 of 22 for 171 yards and a touchdown. Hurd gained 92 yards on 18 carries. 
Coker finished 21 of 27 for 247 yards with an interception. Stewart had six catches for 114 yards. 
Both quarterbacks were sacked five times. 
"I thought our team showed some grit, some determination and some resiliency on the road against a quality opponent, a top 10 opponent, in a hostile environment to go down and drive the ball and put us in a position to win," Jones said. "At the University of Tennessee, there are no moral victories." 
Alabama has won the last nine meetings, and the Vols have dropped 24 straight against Top 10 teams. 
This one was anything but a mismatch in the long-running rivalry. 
Tennessee kicker Aaron Medley missed a 43-yard attempt and two 51-yarders, one on the final play of the first half and the other early in the fourth quarter. Jones is standing by his kicker. 
"Those were very difficult kicks but there isn't any other kicker that I want instead of Aaron," the coach said. 
Tennessee started two freshmen on the offensive line, right guard Jack Jones and right tackle Chance Hall. 
Alabama wore No. 28 stickers on their helmets honoring former teammate Altee Tenpenny, who died in a car accident on Tuesday. 
AP college football website: http://www.collegefootball.ap.org
